title: Space Planning for Online Community
segmentation: Good afternoon, my name is Danielle Fisher.
I am here from Microsoft Research.
I'm presenting this work in conjunction with.
Well, I'm connecting.
I'm presenting this work in conjunction with Mark Smith, who heard this morning and Tamera Turner, who unfortunately is in China and can't be presenting today.
We're all from various bits of Microsoft Research and we've all been interested in online communities for the last few years.
We've been thinking a lot about how we can interact with people who are running communities and people who run online communities of various sorts of income.
And talking to us.
So many people in this room are familiar with various online groups, online communities, blog conversations, wikis, and so on.
All of these are.
Important things, however, that you run into some issues of both size and scale.
When you move up to dealing with the corporate context, there's different sorts of questions that we get concerned about.
There's a larger numbers of situations to talk about, and there is a some economies of scale that need to be thought about.
So Microsoft has a mind boggling number of different online communities that they try and run just some various places where they live.
Is the MSN forums Windows Live spaces?
It's a blogging thing.
The MSDN forums where people talk about technical problems and answers.
Codeplex has a number of forums.
MSDN has a internal wiki, know Channel Nine runs a wiki and some forums and some other stuff.
Not to mention newsgroups.
Third party branded sites, sites that are not completely.

Label this Microsoft, but that we contribute help and effort to, and so on at some point or another, huge number of these different groups have passed through a door talking about online communities, and so we wanted to sort of share some of the challenges that they've run into.
And talk about ways that we've gotten around it.
What I'm going to do then, is talk about sort of eight high points broken into four categories for each of these, I'm going to give you a rough quote.

Something like the situation that we ran into and talk a little bit about what happened, and then I'll sort of give you the didactic lesson of some of the issues that we think might help resolve that.
So we're going to break this into four categories.
Things about the communities, location and purpose.
We're going to talk about monitoring social activity.
About providing feedback to users and ways that you can otherwise organize and.
Maintain this pace.
Now, as Mark pointed out this morning, there's a lot of literature in this space already creases both.
How is X book and?
Why my butt and Amy Jo Kim?

All these are fabulous texts that are important reading and then when we go visit the teams that were coming to us with these issues, they often have 1, two or all three of these books on their shelves, which suggests that even if these issues are well underscored in the literature, there worth bringing out and sort of highlighting how they.
Might feel different here.
So let's start off Designer comes to us and complains that the online community that she created hasn't done anything yet.
It was going to be for the a list of people who were in her particular area and they were going to get all those people in one place and great stuff would happen.
It had been six months and nothing had happened at all.
No.
Had shown up this was in part because the great stuff must happen.
Doesn't quite do it.
You have to have a purpose for communities and in general this communities at Microsoft that have had some sort of fairly specific purpose have been more successful.
This is an airport.
Airports feel like airports and look like airports inside.
They've got all the airport features and they're great for doing air porting in.
You could not build a space that was simultaneously question airport.
It would just throw things off one or the other one.
Be very good at it.
Let's move on.
Person came up to us and said, well, we're trying to figure out a place where people who are administering with the Microsoft Management Console can talk to each other.
It's very important 'cause there's a lot of tricky bits and they want to be able to help each other, they said.
OK, what do you do now?
And they said, well, they tend to use the installation console message boards.
Oh, OK, so how about you put it in the installation console space?
Well, installation console turns out to be run by developer division while management console is run by Windows Division and these are very different organizations.
There are different parts of the come.
They couldn't possibly work together.
Of course, that's an external.
That's an internal distinction.
People at Microsoft very deeply care about our organizational differences.
People outside the company really don't care, so the second piece of advice that we've been giving as often as possible was to build on the existing community and brand outside.
It's all just Microsoft or whatever your favorite organization is.
And if you can possibly find a way to erase those internal divisions, and you know instead of the world with happy little blue balls all painted in the same colors, things will be much.
More coherent.
Mark alluded earlier to talk to issues about community return on investment about groups having a successful reach and impact.
And the question of course is, will our community survive?
So people want to know whether it's worth the energy to put this in.
We have spent a fair bit of time digging through literature trying to find return on investment on community.
There's been one or two Forrester reports on it.
There's been a couple of things in academia, but I don't think anyone has successfully yet figured out whether it's worth the dollars to run an online community or not.

We've been able to do some handwaving about this, we for example being able to talk with groups and to estimate how much they expect the answers that show up on a forum cost them to provide as opposed to the answers that they'd have to provide through a help desk or an answer through a phone call or an answer through a personal email.
And it turns out, of course, that putting up an answer on the web is a much, much better thing than having it.
Then giving it in person.
Because then it's archived.
It's collected and can be kept, but in general we wanted to encourage groups to have some sense of what their space is doing.
Once they knew something about what the community is, how the community is interacting.
They'd be able to make much more informed statements about return on investment, so you may not be able to have an underground.
NORAD radar installation, for example, but you can have some visualizations like Mark was showing this morning.

So to go back to one of the images we were talking about the scatter plot on the X axis is the number of posts in any thread in the News Group on the Y axis is the number of days that given user has been active on the newsgroup.
Each bubble represents a single user, so the users towards the top on the left side, or people who have been on the News Group a whole lot have interact.

And have since there on the left side they've had very short threads, very short conversations, people further down, have had fewer interactions on the group, and many of those have had noticeably longer conversations.
This is the pattern that mark referred to, and that we refer to as the question and answer pattern.
So up there are answer people.
They show up.
They answer a question they leave, they show up the answer question.
If they do this a whole lot of times, that's 300 days per year.
At those bubbles on the top on the bottom is everyone else.
There's sort of floating around in the.
Space of showing up under 100 times a year so they have a couple of questions they show up.
They ask something they go away.
Vast majority of the group is not bottom section.
The top bit has a fewer peep.

It's someone comes in and says this is it's no longer just.
How do I solve this problem, but.
Why is Microsoft foisting off this piece of crap on us and has to be responded to and discussed and argued out in all its various permutations and combinations?

Success of your community.

What could they possibly do about these free riders who aren't contributing?

It's perfectly OK to have free riders.
That's why we post on public websites.

The answer people and these are great to cultivate.

Cat OK for a lot of these groups.

Of course, if some social psychology experiments in the last few years, Paul Resnik has shown that if you do have those leaders go out and welcome people who have shown up in the group and give them positive feedback for having participated, they're more likely in turn to turn into group leaders and regulars.
Let's go back in steps.
Groups are looking for ways to reward interaction and find ways to help users know that.

You can get.

At you can look at a single users or someone else's profile, or look at your own profile.

And people have a negative reputation.
Get slammed down into the ground and kicked out of the site, and man then will only have good people on our site which.
Works just fine.

Means that the person who was determined to cause trouble will simply leave and go cause trouble again.

Paul Resnik, again, actually has done research on the value of eBay reputation, and he was essentially able to show that people were willing to misbehave to the level of the value of the reputation that they already accumulated.
That is to say.

If you've been spending a whole lot of time on eBay, you've got this great reputation and you've bought a whole lot of stuff at really good transactions, and you're completely unwilling to allow some bad interaction to Sully this, you know, unless it's really worth a whole lot of money.
Conversely, if your brand new on eBay, it doesn't matter if you misbehave, because after all, what can you do?
You can go register for new account.

In contrast, people who are sincere, really wanting to help out, but now they've gotten their name smudged because they misbehaved and got a negative reputation are also discouraged from interacting because now they're afraid that they're going to walk around stigmatized.
So I'm in.

I'm strongly in favor of positive reputation systems if you can make people who are doing well know that they're doing well, and people who are doing better than that know that they're doing even better than that, then you've got a great system for encouraging people to move upwards.
But negative reputation hasn't, at least in our experience, been as clearly successful.
